pain_points: soreness on top of shoulder
ache during overhead motion
mild stiffness after swimming
warnings: If you experience sharp or worsening pain during any movement, stop immediately and rest.
If pain persists beyond 7 days or you notice decreased strength or range of motion, consult a healthcare professional.
If you develop numbness, tingling, or a sensation of instability in the arm, seek prompt medical evaluation.
exercises: Pendulum Swings: Lean forward with your non‐painful arm supported on a table. Let the painful arm hang and gently swing it in small circles for 1–2 minutes.
Resisted External Rotation: Attach a light resistance band at waist height. With elbow bent 90° and tucked at your side, rotate your forearm outward. Do 2–3 sets of 10–15 reps.
Cross-Body Stretch: Bring the painful arm across your chest and use the opposite hand to pull it closer. Hold for 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.

Doorway Pec Stretch: Stand in a doorway with elbow and shoulder at 90°. Place your forearm on the frame and gently lean forward until you feel a stretch in the front shoulder/chest. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.

Scapular Retraction (Wall Angels): Stand with your back against a wall, arms in a “W” shape. Slide your arms upward into a “Y,” keeping wrists and elbows in contact with the wall. Perform 2–3 sets of 8–12 reps.

pain_points: dull ache along the quadriceps
discomfort with bending or walking
warnings: If you experience significant swelling, bruising, or inability to bear weight, seek medical attention.
If pain worsens or persists beyond 5–7 days, consult a healthcare professional.
If you develop numbness, tingling, or severe weakness in the leg, seek prompt evaluation.
exercises: Standing Quadriceps Stretch: Stand on one leg, pull your opposite heel toward your glutes, keeping knees close. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.
Hamstring Stretch: Lie on your back, loop a towel around your foot and straighten your leg overhead until you feel a stretch. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.
Straight Leg Raises: Lie on your back with one knee bent and the other straight. Lift the straight leg to hip height, hold 2 seconds, then lower slowly. Perform 2–3 sets of 10–15 reps.
Glute Bridge: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat. Lift hips until your body forms a straight line, squeeze glutes, hold 2–3 seconds, then lower. Perform 2–3 sets of 10–12 reps.
Foam Roller Quadriceps Massage: Lie face down, place a foam roller under your thigh, and roll gently from hip to knee for 1–2 minutes.

pain_points: mild to moderate soreness on the front of the thigh
tenderness when contracting the quadriceps (knee extension)
muscle fatigue or cramping during activities such as kicking or walking
warnings: If you notice significant swelling, bruising, or cannot bear weight, seek medical attention immediately.
If pain worsens or does not improve after 5–7 days of rest and self-care, consult a healthcare professional.
If you develop numbness, tingling, or severe weakness in the leg, seek prompt evaluation.
exercises: Standing Quadriceps Stretch: Stand on one leg, pull the opposite heel toward your glutes, keeping knees close. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times per side.
Foam Roller Quadriceps Massage: Lie face down, place a foam roller under your right thigh, and roll gently from hip to knee for 1–2 minutes.
Straight Leg Raises: Lie on your back with one knee bent and the other leg straight. Lift the straight leg to hip height, hold for 2 seconds, then lower slowly. Perform 2–3 sets of 10–15 reps.
Prone Hip Flexor Stretch: Lie face down, prop on forearms, gently squeeze your right glute to tilt the pelvis and stretch the front of your thigh. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.
Bodyweight Squats (Pain-Free Range): Stand feet hip-width apart, squat only as far as you can without pain, then return to standing. Perform 2–3 sets of 10–12 reps.

pain_points: dull to sharp pain in left pectoral region during breaststroke pull
aching or tightness after swimming
pain aggravated by pressing arms together or reaching across chest
warnings: If you experience chest pain with shortness of breath, sweating, dizziness or nausea, seek emergency care immediately.
If pain is sharp, severe, or associated with bruising or swelling of the chest, stop activity and see a healthcare professional.
If discomfort persists beyond 7 days despite rest and self-care, consult a physical therapist or physician.
exercises: Doorway Pec Stretch: Stand in a doorway, place forearm on frame at shoulder height, lean forward until you feel a gentle stretch in the front of your chest. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times each side.
Foam Roller Chest Opener: Lie face-up on a foam roller placed lengthwise along your spine, let arms fall out to sides, palms up. Breathe deeply for 1–2 minutes.
Isometric Adduction Press: Stand or sit, press your palms together in front of your sternum at shoulder height, hold 5 seconds, relax. Repeat 10 times.
Scapular Retraction: Sit or stand tall, squeeze shoulder blades together as if pinching a pencil between them, hold 5 seconds, release. Repeat 10–15 times.
Cross-Body Shoulder Stretch: Bring your left arm across your chest and use your right hand to gently pull it closer. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.

pain_points: soreness during writing
pain when gripping a pen or pencil
tightness in the forearm muscles after short writing sessions
warnings: If you experience numbness or tingling in the fingers, seek medical attention.
If pain worsens or does not improve after 7 days of rest and self‐care, consult a healthcare professional.
If you notice significant weakness in your grip or loss of wrist motion, see a professional promptly.
exercises: Wrist Extension Stretch: Extend your right arm with palm facing down. Use your left hand to gently pull the fingers back toward you until you feel a stretch on top of your forearm. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.

Wrist Flexion Stretch: Extend your right arm with palm facing up. Gently pull your fingers down and toward you with your left hand until you feel a stretch in the underside of your forearm. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.
Forearm Pronation/Supination: Hold a lightweight or a hammer handle vertically. Rotate your forearm so your palm faces up, then down. Perform 2 sets of 10 slow repetitions each direction.
Towel-Wringing Exercise: Roll up a small towel. Grasp each end and twist as if you’re wringing water out, first clockwise, then counter-clockwise. Do 2 sets of 10 twists each way.
Self-Massage: Use your thumb to apply gentle, sustained pressure along the length of the forearm muscles (from elbow to wrist) for 1–2 minutes to release tension.

pain_points: feeling of tightness in the back of the lower leg
mild discomfort when dorsiflexing the ankle
muscle stiffness after prolonged standing or exercise
warnings: If you experience severe pain, significant swelling or bruising, or cannot bear weight, seek medical attention immediately.
If calf tightness or discomfort persists beyond 5–7 days despite self-care, consult a healthcare professional.
If you notice numbness, tingling, or changes in skin color (paleness or redness), seek prompt evaluation.
exercises: Calf Stretch Against Wall: Stand facing a wall with hands at shoulder height. Step your left leg back, keep the heel down and knee straight. Lean forward until you feel a stretch in the upper calf. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.

Seated Towel Stretch: Sit with legs extended. Loop a towel around the ball of your left foot, gently pull the towel toward you while keeping the knee straight until you feel a stretch. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.

Soleus (Bent-Knee) Calf Stretch: Stand facing a wall, place hands on the wall. Step your left leg back and bend both knees slightly, keeping the heel of the back foot on the ground. Lean in until you feel a stretch lower in the calf. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.

Foam Roller Calf Release: Sit on the floor with a foam roller under your left calf. Support yourself with your hands and roll slowly from just above the ankle to below the knee for 1–2 minutes, pausing on tender spots.
Heel Raises: Stand feet hip-width apart, holding a chair for balance. Rise onto your toes, squeeze calves at the top for 2 seconds, then lower slowly. Perform 2–3 sets of 12–15 reps.

muscle stiffness after prolonged standing or exercise

pain_points: general tightness in the abdominal muscles
discomfort during core exercises
soreness when bending or twisting
warnings: If you experience sharp or severe abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting, seek medical attention promptly.
If abdominal pain is accompanied by any signs of hernia (a visible bulge or sensation of weakness), consult a healthcare professional immediately.
If discomfort persists beyond 7 days despite self-care, consider consulting a physical therapist.

additional Tool use: I will send specific abdominal stretches for you.
